text: The concert is over. The audience breaks up. Ethan and Grace, arm around each other (like lovers), move through groups of parents. Ethan carries his son’s Cello. Josh plays with his sister Emma and some other kids by a tree, they are catching fireflies.
Mr. Learner, Mr. Learner! Ethan turns. An ELEGANT LADY (40s) catches up, thrusts her hand out to Ethan.
Evelyn Williams. My son Jed is in your media studies class. He just loves that course. (CONTINUED )
Jed’s a clever guy, and fun to be around. You should be proud. This is my wife Grace. Josh and Emma run towards their parents. They shake hands.
Hello. Do you teach also?
No, I’m a landscape designer. A tug on Grace’s skirt.
Mommy, mommy, look what Josh has got for me.
We must get going. Tell Jed I said hello. Emma holds a glass peanut jar filled with fireflies.
Fireflies. They’re magic!
Thanks again, good night. Grace walks away with Ethan who has his arm around her waist. Josh arrives, his hands cupped.
I’ve got another one.
You were excellent, Josh.
You played beautifully. Josh is busy putting the firefly in the jar.
Thanks, Dad. They arrive at their car, get in.
It’s dark now. A VOLVO STATION WAGON travels along a country road. GRACE (V.O. A big bath as soon as you get back young lady.
Ethan drives, Grace beside him. Josh and Emma in the back. (Prairie Home Companion is on the radio).
The orchestra conductor says you're going inot the Northeast finals this semester. That’s exciting.
Yeah, we have practice Tuesdays and Saturdays.
Saturdays? What about our canoe trips?
I don’t know, dad. It’s the finals. Garrison Kellior on the radio: “It got cold in Lake Wobegon, like your father just walked into the room.”
What does that mean?
I guess some people’s fathers are...how would you say it?
They're severe, cross. They make people tremble.
Like when Mrs. Prendegast walks in the room at school. (CONTINUED )
No. Mrs. Prendegast isn’t that bad.
Mom! Josh and Emma begin to study the fireflies. Ethan switches on the wipers, pushes the wiper button to clean the dirty screen. Nothing.
(mutters) Damn.
Mommy Can I keep them in my room forever?
I don’t think so sweetie, they might die. Emma starts crying.
I don’t want them to die. Will they die in the jar?
It’s okay, we’ll let them go when we get home, won’t we Josh.
Sure, mom. The Volvo signals left and turns on to Reservation Road.
The road, narrow and unlit, flanked by woods. Ahead lies A COUNTRY GAS STATION. INT. ETHAN’S CAR - CONTINUOUS 6
I need to pee. (CONTINUED )
Can't it wait darling?
No mommy.

It’s alright. I need to get wiper fluid anyway. The Volvo pulls in and stops. Ethan, Grace and Emma get out. Josh picks up the glass jar, studies it. CLOSE ON the glass jar. There are two dead fireflies at the bottom of the jar.
Ethan walks into the workshop. The AUTO REPAIRMAN, JIMMY MCBRIDE, looks up from an engine repair job. An old 13 inch TV, with rabbit ears, plays in a corner.
Working late tonight?
Every night. Ethan already has a gallon of fluid in hand.
How much?
Give me three dollars. IN THE BACKGROUND, a sports news report on TV.
A marathon session at Fenway ended tonight with the Sox winning 6-4 in the twelfth. Ethan hands over three dollars.
Twelve innings. You’re not the only one working late.
Different pay scale. (CONTINUED )
For sure. Is this stuff bio- degradeable?
Whatever it says on the label.
A FORD EXPLORER comes barrelling around a corner.

Ethan steps out into the night, reading the label, then looks up as a CAR comes from his left, the road is illuminated and in the blaze of light (from brights). He sees Josh standing between two clumps of bushes on an aisle by the road. Then there is a SCREECH of tires, and, suddenly, from his right, the dark SUV careens into the light of the car then they pass. Ethan is frozen, about to turn as the SUV veers toward his son.
Grace is holding the door open for Emma when she hears the awful tone of Ethan’s warning.
Ethan, frozen, makes out the shape of a man driving the SUV as it swerves in toward the aisle and his son steps back.
DWIGHT ARNO (40ish) sees the terrified face of a young boy frozen in his headlights. He tries to brake. His cell phone flies against the windscreen.  13 14 15 16 17
The peanut jar falls, crashing through the grill and smashes the passenger side headlight of the SUV.
Ethan watches in terror as the SUV HITS JOSH, BOUNCES him sideways, and he disappears behind the clump of trees.
Josh's body flies off to the side. At the same time: Inside, LUCAS ARNO (11), is asleep in the passenger seat. He flies forward, his face smashes into the dashboard.
Ethan is RUNNING NOW across the forecourt out onto the road. Behind him, A CRY:
Ethan! As he runs, he catches a glimpse of the red brake lights on the SUV further along the road.
Inside, Dwight reaches across to Lucas, who is doubled up in pain, clutching his eye.
Are you alright? Then, Dwight looks in the mirror, sees a man (Ethan) standing in the road, staring, but Lucas is crying now.
Dad, dad, my eye! (CONTINUED )
Oh, Jesus! Jesus!
It hurts. Dwight cradles Lucas in his arms, on his face a look of absolute terror. Then a BUZZING SOUND.
Ethan calls out to the SUV.
Hey!
Where’s Josh?! Josh! Ethan turns back toward the verge.
Josh! Then, the sound of an ENGINE REVVING. The SUV takes off. Ethan reaches Josh but, confused, he turns toward the fleeing SUV. He shouts, begins to run after it ...
Hey! Stop!
Dwight looks in the mirror again, then puts his foot on the gas.
It’s alright, I’m gonna take care of it. Don’t cry, please. The Ford Explorer speeds off into the night. Dwight reaches over to Lucas.
Come on, stop crying.
Now Ethan sees Josh, lifeless, blood trickling from his ears. He falls to his knees beside his child. (CONTINUED )
Oh, God, oh God, you’re alright, you're alright ... AAAHHH! A CRY OF PAIN, as he kneels on shattered glass.
(beyond terrified)
He looks back, sees Grace running toward him, then, confused, she turns back toward Emma, who is frozen mid- forecourt.
Come on, stop crying, let me see. Lucas turns to him, the eye has begun to swell up.
What happened Dad?
We hit a log. It was lying on the road. I’m sorry. It’s gonna be alright.
A King Kullen supermarket on the edge of town. Dwight’s Ford Explorer pulls into the almost deserted car park.
I‘1l only be a second. Dwight sprints across the car park.
From outside, we see Dwight’s anxious trot along the aisles, past the registers, as he disappears, and reappears with a bag in hand.
Dwight jumps into the car. He has a pack of frozen peas. (CONTINUED )
Let me see that. Lucas turns his head, a full blown shiner is developing.
Here, put this on it.
Peas! Dad!

They're frozen ... like an ice pack. Pitchers use it on their arms. As Lucas places the frozen pea pack on his eye, Dwight starts the Explorer. A STATE TROOPER CAR, SIRENS BLARING, LIGHTS FLASHING, races past on the road.
What happened Dad?
We hit a log, a tree branch on the road. You didn’t see it?
No dad. I didn’t see anything.
Sounds first: CRICKETS, RADIO SQUAWK and STATIC. Then the state trooper car pulls in to join several others blocking roads at the accident site.
Anything?

Negative. An AMBULANCE’S warping red light competes with the flashing lights of PATROL CARS in front of the gas station. SEVERAL POLICE are at work, stringing tape, directing cars away, taking measurements. Grace, visible in the backseat of the car, face tear- stained, lifeless. Emma curled on her lap, like a baby. (CONTINUED )
Ethan stands in the middle of the road, stares over at the covered body of his son. He looks dead, crushed.
Sir? SERGEANT KEN BURKE (40-ish), clean-cut, pulls a notebook and pen from his back pocket.

I'm afraid I need to ask you some questions about what occurred here. Ethan just stares at him. Underwater. SERGEANT BURKE (CONT’D) Can you tell us exactly what you saw? Mr. Learner ... I have to do this, we have a crime, a fugitive and time is of the essence.
Sorry.
It’s a terrible thing, Mr. Learner, but I need your best recollection.
Yes. (beat) I was getting washer fluid.
What time would this have been?
Time? I don’t ... it must have been close to nine. The game report was on ... on the TV. I came out ...
Grace has Emma’s head buried in her chest.
Where’s Josh, Mommy? Grace's POV of the medics hovering over her dead son. (CONTINUED )
They're taking care of him.
Is he going to be alright? Grace watches as the paramedics lift the body bag, she’s dying inside, but tries not to lie.
I... ahh ... your daddy’s with him. She holds Emma’s head against her so she can’t look.
And the vehicle that hit your son came from the right? Ethan manages a nod. SERGEANT BURKE (CONT’D) Could you describe it for me?
A truck, an SUV...
You get the make?
No. Big ... medium ... dark, blue maybe.
Could you describe the driver? Ethan is frozen by his own uncertainty.
He was ... ah ... no. Burke waits for more.
Oh Christ ... I don’t know. It’s a blur. (CONTINUED )
What was your son doing on the road? Ethan looks at him with tears in his eyes.
(beyond pathetic) I don’t know. A long silence. Burke slips the notebook into his back pocket and clips the pen to his shirt.
I understand. We’1ll continue tomorrow. One of my guys will drive you home. But Ethan’s no longer listening. Lost in the nightmare of his own helplessness, staring at the body bag.
I’m not leaving my son.

I’m sorry Mr. Learner but need to keep the body here for now. It’s a crime scene. I’m going to make sure everything is handled with the greatest respect. You’ve got family to look after. Please go home. The word ‘body’ cuts Ethan like a sword.
Ethan gets in the back seat. A STATE TROOPER in the driver seat. Emma has cried herself asleep.
Where are we going?
Home.
Home? The word is poison to her.  29 14.

A Colonial house with a porch. A couple of lights on inside. RUTH WHELDON (mid-30s) is at the window, staring out. The Explorer turns into the driveway and stops with the single headlight beam shining over the porch. The door opens, Ruth emerges, flashlight in hand. She shines the flashlight toward Dwight.
What happened to you? She shines the light directly into Dwight’s face. (How could she know already?)
Why, what’s wrong?
You’re more than two hours late. Now the light is on Lucas and she sees him hold something to his eye as Dwight gets out of the SUV. RUTH (CONT’D) What the hell happened to him?
Take it easy Ruth. Now Lucas gets out, reveals his eye.
Oh my God! Did you do this?
What! Are you crazy?
Mom, wait.
Look at him! Lucas is between them now. (CONTINUED )
Please mom, it was an accident. We hit a log.
There was a downed tree branch or something on a bend. We went over it and his head hit the ...
Why wasn’t he wearing a seat belt?
He was ... he messed with it. I didn’t see him.
(as she examines Lucas) Oh God, look at this, you know what people are going to think?
No Ruth, what are they going to think?
That you hit him again.
When are you going to get off that lie. I did not hit him, I tried to hit you and I missed. NORRIS WHELDON (40-ish), insurance salesman, Ruth’s husband, rushes out of the house, intervenes.
Hey, hey! Please, everyone take it easy. Let me see that Lucas.
Where the hell were you?
We were at the ball game for Christ sake. Where the hell did you think we were?
Who knows with you. You’re two hours late. I called ten times. (CONTINUED )
Dwight looks to Lucas.
One month, just one month you’ve been allowed to have him over the weekend and he comes back looking like this. Every time I cut you some slack, you mess it up.
You cut me slack?!
You wanna go back before the court? I’11 have your visitation rights pulled in a heartbeat.
Please, everyone, lets take one step back from this. Dwight everything’s fine, get in the car. Ruth examines Lucas eye.
(to Norris) Do you think he needs to go to the hospital?
Don’t be so ...
Dwight please! Ruth take Lucas inside. As Ruth leads Lucas away.
(to Lucas) Hey, you okay?
Yeah, Dad, I’1l1 call you tomorrow. Dwight smiles, nods “yes.”
Hey Dad, (holds up the peas) pee ... nuts. (CONTINUED )
Ruth throws a disgusted look back at Dwight. Norris meanwhile has shone his light on the broken headlight.
You better get that light fixed, Dwight. You’ll get ticketed.
Yeah. Thanks Norris.
A dog - SALLIE, hears something, pricks up its ears, bounds to the living room window, looks out.

A handsome old New England house, set amid a pleasant garden. A COP CAR pulls away as Ethan carries Emma towards the door. Grace follows closely into the house. EXT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE. GARAGE - NIGHT 31 A two-bedroom ranch-style, with a single car garage. A place devoid of personality, a divorcee’s rental. Dwight pulls into the driveway. He lifts the remote for the garage door, starts it, then changes his mind. He gets out, walks around to the front passenger side, studies the grill guard and the broken headlight. INT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE - NIGHT 32 Dwight paces into the living room, turns on TV, clicks through the STATIONS, and finds the local news, a report on deadlock in the Connecticut State Legislature. He wanders over to the door, he’s left the main door open, gazes through the screen door at the SUV. He goes to the phone, dials.
(into phone) Connecticut, Stratton. Stratton police station. Dwight listens, mutters a number, hangs up. Then fumbles for a pen, scribbles, studies the number. (CONTINUED )
He opens the freezer, pulls out a bottle of Stoli vodka, pours some into a glass, takes a big swig, then spits it out.
Shit, fuck, shit! He collapses onto the couch.
Ethan is in their bed with Emma, who has her arms clamped around his neck.
He’s not coming home? Why? She looks to the door in panic.
Where’s mommy? Mommy! (TRACK out the door, along the hall, to the bathroom)
Grace sits on the edge of the bath, listening to the ring of a cellphone, then a woman’s voice, a faint hello.

Mom. Mom, I’ve got some terrible news ... Grace tries to say the words, they can’t come out, instead silence, then gasps, then tears ... collapses, can’t speak. INT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE - DAWN 34 Dwight is still on the couch, most of the bottle of vodka gone, and the ashtray full. He surf’s the RADIO STATIONS, stops at the local station. A News Reporter talking again about the deadlock at the State Legislature. Dwight gets up, wanders to screen door, sees the first rays of a glorious sunrise. Dwight’s POV of the Ford Explorer. (CONTINUED )

Connecticut state troopers are investigating a fatal hit and run accident on Reservation Road near Old Greenwich. The victim is believed to be a ten year old boy. No name has been released but State Troopers are appealing to anyone driving in the vicinity around 9 PM last night to contact them at 1-800-555-1212. On I-95 a tractor trailer accident closed down the southbound highway for over two hours last night ... CLOSE ON his face, forehead flat against the door window, as though his whole body needs support.

A set of blinds open on a window revealing a glorious sunrise on a very pleasant back garden. The light streams in on Ethan, still in his t-shirt and boxers red eyed, from lack of sleep. He stares into the mirror, sees a spiderman towel hanging over the shower bar (or door). He takes it down, folds it carefully. EXT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE - DAY (FORMERLY SCENE 39) 35A Dwight emerges, gets into the Explorer, and drives it into the garage. He gets out and pushes a button on the wall and ducks under the door as it starts to close. The evidence sealed up, he starts back to his house.
Ethan, lies on the bed beside Grace. Emma asleep on the other side. He holds her.
I've got to go pick up the car. Your mother should be here soon. He goes to her, leans, kisses. (CONTINUED )
Don’t be long, please. The doorbell rings.
That can’t be mom?
Ethan opens the front door. BLANCA, a Hispanic woman, with cleaning equipment in her hand, smiles.
Good morning, Mr. Learner.
(shocked) Oh Blanca, it’s your day.
Grace settles and looks at Emma sleeping then, a PIERCING CRY from downstairs.
Ahh, no! No not my Josh! Blanca’s voice cuts the air.
Grace rushes down the stairs in her nightdress and sees Ethan trying to console BLANCA.

Oh, Blanca, Blanca. Blanca has known Josh since he was a little boy. Her grief is raw. Emma stands at the top of the stairs looking frightened. INT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE. BEDROOM - DAY (FORMERLY SCENE 36) 38 Dwight asleep, still clothed, in the fetal position, on the bed. He awakens, looks at the clock, it’s 10:05. He jumps up, rushes out.  39 40 41 21.

CLOSE ON a thickset HISPANIC DRIVER who laughs at a joke by the morning DRIVETIME DJ. Ethan, in the back, scribbles in a note pad, raises his head, stares out the window at the work day morning hustle on this busy street: SCHOOL KIDS ON BIKES, COMMUTERS scurrying to the local train station, A COUPLE OF 14 YEAR OLDS, boy and girl, holding hands as they walk to school. Ethan’s cell rings, he studies the number, it reads DEAN PHILIP CLARKSON, he answers. The driver lowers the radio.

Hey Phil ... yeah. Sorry I can’t, Phil ... ah ... I’m not going to make it in today ... No, no... a family thing ... in fact, I’m not going to be in for a while. Ethan listens, as he’s asked what’s wrong, finally he drops his head, confesses.
Look Phil, we've had a tragedy ... Josh was killed last night.
(muffled) Jesus Christ, Ethan! How?
Hit and run. (a beat) Thanks, thank you. Let me call you later. CLOSE ON The rearview mirror and the driver's eyes.
A Victorian house just outside the center of town. Clipped hedges out front and a small parking lot behind. A painted sign reads “Cutter and Associates.” (CONTINUED )
A (similar) cab pulls up. Dwight gets out in a hurry.
Dwight hurries past the middle-aged, frumpy RECEPTIONIST, who is on the phone. He heads down the corridor.
Hey Dwight. INT. CUTTER & ASSOCIATES. STEVE CUTTER’S OFFICE - DAY 42A A smartly dressed, handsome man (50ish). This is Steve CUTTER, the owner and principle lawyer of the firm.
You in court this morning?
Nah, car trouble, the fucking transmission went on the Explorer yesterday, spent the morning dealing with it.
How'd it go with Lucas this weekend?
Really good, why?
I got a call from Ruth this morning, said you were belligerent, brought Lucas home with a black eye.
Bitch. He smacked his eye on the dash. She threw a shit fit.

Look buddy, you can’t get into situations with her. She drags us in front of that judge again you'll loose the sleep over. Nora Fennelli’s waiting. Dwight nods, mutters fuck to himself as he leaves.  23. 43 INT. CUTTER & ASSOCIATES. DWIGHT’S OFFICE - DAY 43 Dwight hurries in. NORA FENNELLI is reading an old New Yorker magazine.
Hey Nora, how are you?
Bored. I’ve been sitting here for forty minutes.
Sorry, car trouble. You look good. Have you lost weight?
Only in my purse, thanks to the bills I get from you guys.
Sunlight. The state trooper offices, clean, modern. The cab pulls up at the entrance. Ethan hands the driver some money.
Keep the change. As Ethan walks up the steps, he sees a battered old SUV, (dark blue) on a truck flat bed. He hurries.
Did you get him? 45 INT. STATE POLICE BARRACKS. BURKE’S OFFICE - DAY 45 Ethan sits across from Sgt. Burke.
No, I’m afraid not.
I saw an SUV out there.
Similar? (CONTINUED )
Well yeah, dark, the same shape. ETHAN’S POV - THROUGH A WINDOW - of the SUV. SERGEANT BURKE. We’ve had that since Saturday. You think that might be the model?
Well something like that. They sit again.
Good, we're getting somewhere. Let’s look at some similar makes.
What are the chances of this man turning himself in?
In the first few days, very good. He’s drunk or high, he goes home, sobers up, realizes what he’s done and turns himself in. The longer it goes then surrender becomes less likely.
INT. STATE POLICE BARRACKS. BURKE’S OFFICE - LATER 46 CLOSE ON a Starbucks coffee cup placed on a desk.
Decaf latte. Ethan nods as the State Trooper sets it down. Ethan’s been there awhile now - files, photos are spread across Burke’s desk. Ethan sips, thinking, then ...
He shouted something.
Who did?
The driver. Yeah, that’s right a shout, sounded like Lo ... Look. (CONTINUED )
Look out maybe.
I don’t know, I didn’t hear anymore.
No one else in the truck?
No, I didn’t see anyone. It all happened in a flash.
Did you notice anything unusual about the vehicle, snow plough attachment, grill guard. Ethan shakes his head “no,” uncomfortable with his lack of memory.
The reason I ask is that we usually find some debris from the impact: paint flakes, fiber glass, dirt the wheel well. There was none of that at the scene.
It was all so fast. Burke lifts some evidence bags from a box.

We gathered up some items from around the scene, perhaps you could take a look. The first bag contains some crushed soda cans, empty cigarette pakcs. Ethan studies, shakes his head no. The Burke reaches in takes out another bag, its the peanut jar, intact, the lid is separate, the fireflies are gone. Etha’s look registers with Burke. SERGEANT BURKE (CONT’D) You recognize that.
No.It is a peanut jar. Josh collected fireflies in it. (CONTINUED )
You think that’s why he got out of your car? To collect fireflies.
No. to let them go.
Burke walks Ethan to his car.

This is a small town, Mr. Learner. We’ve mobilized all our resources. I'm hopeful we'll find this vehicle and catch this man quickly. Ethan acknowledges the support. Sergeant Burke hands Ethan a brown envelope. SERGEANT BURKE (CONT’D) Victims Services have put together a package of brochures, advise about practical and legal aspect of dealing with this sort of crime. All our numbers are in there. Call any time.
Thanks. Ethan gets in the Volvo, still dazed from the peanut jar revelation.
Inside, Dwight heads toward the exit door, stops momentarily at Cutter’s door. Steve is on the phone.
(on phone) One second ... (CONTINUED )
I gotta get a rental ‘till I figure this car thing out.
Dwight steps outside, a TAXI is waiting. He tries to breathe fresh air into his lungs. As he stands, Ethan’s car drives by.

Sunlight. Grace is at the kitchen table, doing nothing. Shuffling papers, staring at Emma who sits on the outside porch drawing for her GRANDMOTHER BETH. Grace sees Ethan come up the porch stairs, take Beth is his arms, they embrace, profoundly. Ethan enters,
It’s good your mother’s here. Grace gets up, moves toward him.
What did they say? Did they get anyone? He takes her in his arms. The embrace holds.
No. They don’t have anything yet.
Not anything?
Nothing.
Did you remember anything? Anything more? (CONTINUED )
I ahh, yeah I went over what I saw, tried to pick the make of his truck. Details. The embrace breaks, she looks in his eyes.
What was he doing out of the car, Ethan? He’s silent, but Grace knows Ethan, reads his face.
What?
Nothing.
Tell me Ethan.
They found the peanut jar ...
The firefly jar? Where?
Broken, on the road.
Oh Jesus, It was my fault. He was letting them go because I told him they might die! Ethan grabs her hands, holds on.
It was nobody’s fault.
But he went to the bushes, all over the stupid fireflies. Emma appears behind them holding a drawing.
What happened to the fireflies? Did they die with Josh? Her grandmother scoops her up.  53 54
EXT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE - DAY 54 Dwight pulls up into the driveway in a rented, light colored, mid-size car, and parks it under the tree.

Ethan’s car pulls up. As he walks away from it we see he is at Reservation Road Now in the afternoon sunlight, autumn trees, under a clear sky. He walks the road, sees a softball square, an old cemetery. He wanders to the gas station. He stands by the gas pumps, staring up the road. Trying to force himself to see clues he missed.
Again, the setting idyllic, trimmed bushes, carefully groomed lawn, fake roman pillars around the entrance to add style to the building. Ethan pulls up.
The interior tastefully depressing, wood panelling, abundant flowers soothing music. Ethan sits opposite the FUNERAL DIRECTOR.
Were you thinking of cremation or burial? Ethan is stunned by the choice.
Cremation, no? I don’t know ...
Some people prefer to have a place in a garden of remembrance to visit, care for. Others prefer cremation so that they can perhaps release the ashes in a favorite place ...
Late night. Grace and Ethan are at the kitchen table alone.
.».. we can bury him in the cemetery, among the lines of headstones. Or we can take him to the place he loved most in the world, and let him become part of that. He takes her hand pulls her closer.
Let’s take him to the shore. He kisses her, wipes tears from her eyes.
Will I see him, one last time, the way he was?
Tomorrow.
I’m going mad Ethan. Why did this happen to us? What did we do to deserve this?

Don’t, we’ll get through it. They kiss, and cling to each other. INT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE. KITCHEN - DAY 59 CLOSE ON the local newspaper headline. “LOCAL BOY KILLED IN HIT AND RUN - POLICE APPEAL FOR HELP.” Pull back from photo and reveal: Dwight studying the photo, reading the article, the newspaper spread out on his breakfast bar. He drops his head and bangs it on the newspaper, again and again, harder and harder.  61 62 31.
The same newspaper is on the counter top. Ethan has his arm around Grace as they read it together. They are in their funeral clothes
Who gave them that photo?
It’s a school photo. It doesn’t matter. CLOSE ON the school photo of Josh smiling. Grace’s mother arrives in the kitchen with Emma, both dressed for the funeral.
Here we are. Ethan picks Emma up in his arms.
We'd better go.
Dwight’s rental car pulls up and parks. He switches off the engine and stares out at: A church, some 100 yards away.

CLOSE ON the puzzled faces of SCHOOLBOYS and GIRLS - Josh's classmates - not used to dealing with death. This small Episcopalian church is crowded with Ethan’s FELLOW PROFESSORS, FAMILY AND FRIENDS, and a contingent of SCHOOL CHILDREN, who have gathered for this ceremony.

Ruth Wheldon, from High River school and some of her choir will sing Amazing Grace. Feel free to sing along in celebration of Josh. A SMALL CHOIR including LUCAS plays. Ruth Wheldon is on the piano, they launch into Amazing Grace, many in the church join in.  63 64 65 66 32.

Dwight sits in his rental car, looks toward the church further down the street as the CROWD emerges from the service. Dwight takes off his sunglasses, stares. He watches as Ethan and Grace emerge with Emma, hand in hand between them. Dwight’s heart is pounding, his hand trembles, as though Ethan will look up and recognize him. He puts the sunglasses back on. Then his eyes widen in shock, because: He sees his ex-wife Ruth emerge from the church and console Ethan and Grace. Dwight starts the car, does a u-turn in the street, and takes off.

The coffin has been placed in the HEARSE. Ethan, and Grace watch. GRACE’S MOTHER holds on to Emma. As the hearse pulls away, Grace can no longer hold her composure, she moves away from Ethan toward the hearse.
(crying) No, no, please. Josh don’t leave us. Ethan is beside her now holding her as her mother comforts Emma.

It’s Monday morning, a week has gone by. The house, an emblem of New England serenity. Ethan emerges, hand in hand with Emma. Grace in her bathrobe, hair unbrushed - watches from the window. Emma waves goodbye. The car takes off, now Grace is totally alone.  67 68 33.

Close on Grace’s hand as she plugs the power cord of the answering machine back in. Presses play. The recorded message light shows 34. Her finger hovers over the ‘delete all’ button, about to hit it, then she stops, hits ‘play’. She listens to the first word of a message, a distraught voice, “Ethan, Grace...” she hits delete, next is “My God...” Delete. With each message, all Grace needs is the first syllable, then delete, faster, faster, the number dwindles, 22, 17, 11, 9, then the frantic tones of voice disappear. Now we hear “Hello Grace, its Walden, I have those white pines you ordered.” Delete. Grace, Judie Greenberg darling, my rockery’s ... Then:

Hey mom, I need rosin for my cello, it’s on top of my desk. Can you bring them with you? Love you. Bye.” She plays it again, again, transported back before the horror, then a BUZZ, another BUZZ. It’s the doorbell.
Grace opens the door and reveals, A Mexican gardener, RAUL, and behind him out on the road, his TRUCK and his TWO MAN CREW, watching.
Signora Grace, you were to meet us at the Greer house.
Where?
The Greer house, the new job?
Have you got any other work you can do for a few days Raul?, I’m not feeling too good.
(disappointed) I don’t have no big jobs... (CONTINUED )
